title: Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm: I Put Beef Fat on My Face and It Wasn't Weird
body:
Okay so. I bought beef fat for my face. I know. It sounds like something you’d do on a dare in college, or maybe a weird TikTok trend. My first thought was literally “you want me to put what on my skin?” It was a Tuesday night, my heater was clicking like it was angry, and my knuckles looked like a dried-up riverbed. I’d tried the fancy stuff, the drugstore stuff, the stuff in the blue jar my grandma swore by. Nothing stuck. My skin just drank it all up and asked for more. So I was scrolling, half-watching some baking show, and I saw this thing: whipped tallow balm. Bourbon vanilla scent. Made in France. I was skeptical. Very. But also desperate. And curious. So I clicked buy. Here’s what actually happened.

**How I Ended Up Smelling Like Vanilla and Cows**

Let’s rewind. Tallow. It’s beef fat. You cook with it. Your great-grandma probably cooked with it. The idea of slathering it on my cheeks felt… medieval. Or like a prank. But then I started poking around, because that’s what you do at 11 PM when you’re avoiding going to bed. I read that tallow from grass-fed cows is kinda wild because it’s structurally close to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So the idea is it doesn’t just sit on top like a greasy film—it actually gets in there. It’s like your skin recognizes it. “Oh hey, welcome back, we’ve been waiting.” That made a weird kind of sense. My skin was clearly not recognizing the fifteen synthetic creams I’d been feeding it.

Anyway. The jar showed up. Small, glass, simple label. I opened it. Smelled like… vanilla. Good vanilla. Not fake bakery vanilla, but like the kind you’d smell in a fancy candle. Or maybe a old-fashioned candy shop. There was something warm underneath it. Not sweet. Just… warm. The texture threw me. It was solid in the jar but then, the second you swipe a finger, it turns into this cloud. Like whipped butter but lighter. I poked it for a solid minute. My cat watched me like I was insane.

I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand. It was cold for a second, then it just vanished. No shine. No sticky feeling. My skin just… ate it. And felt softer. Not slippery soft. Normal soft. Like my skin but better. Huh.

**Why Beef Tallow for Skin Actually Makes Sense**

So the science-y bit, but I’ll keep it simple because I’m not a scientist. I just read a lot of random articles. Grass-fed beef tallow is packed with fat-soluble vitamins—A, D, E, K. The same ones that are good for you when you eat them, apparently they’re good for your skin too. It’s also got something called conjugated linoleic acid, which sounds like a cleaning product but is supposedly anti-inflammatory. Good for angry, red, itchy skin. Like my winter hands.

But the real thing, the thing that made me go “oh okay fine,” is the history. This isn’t some new, weird bio-hack. People have been using animal fats on their skin for centuries. Forever, probably. Before there was a skincare aisle, there was lard and tallow. It’s the original moisturizer. My own grandma used to rub goose fat on her chest when she had a cold. It’s that kind of old-school, simple wisdom. We just forgot about it because shiny plastic bottles with unpronounceable ingredients seemed more advanced.

We got distracted. I get distracted. Like right now, I just remembered I left my laundry in the washer. Dammit.

Okay. Back. So I started using it. Not on my face at first, no way. I was still too weirded out. I started with my hands. My poor, cracked, bleeding knuckles. After washing dishes. I’d scoop a little, warm it between my palms, and just rub it in. The bourbon vanilla smell is honestly the best part. It’s comforting. It doesn’t smell like food or animals. It just smells nice. Cozy. Like a stress-reducing thing. Within a few days, the cracks started closing up. No joke. They just… healed. Faster than with anything else. That was the moment I thought, maybe this isn’t crazy.

**My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff**

So then I got brave. My face. It was a dry, tight, flaky mess. Winter does that. I’d wake up and it felt like a mask. I used the tiniest amount of the tallow balm. Pea-sized. Warmed it up, pressed it into my skin. Not rubbed, pressed. It soaked in. No greasy pillowcase. No breakout the next day. Nothing.

After a week, my skin just felt… calm. Not miraculously ten years younger. Not “glass skin.” Just calm. Hydrated. The tightness was gone. The little dry patches around my nose vanished. I put it on my elbows too, which have always been rough. They’re smooth now. I keep touching them. It’s weird.

The best part is how simple it is. It’s one jar. One ingredient doing the heavy lifting (well, the tallow is the star, but it’s got some oils and the vanilla for scent). I’m not layering six products anymore. I just wash my face and use this. Sometimes just this. It’s like my skin took a deep breath and finally relaxed. I didn’t expect to become a person who evangelizes about beef fat, but here I am. I got one for my mom. She called me skeptical too, then texted me two weeks later asking for the link.

**Would I Buy This Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm Again?**

Yeah. I already did. I’m on my second jar. I got mine from this little Etsy shop that makes it in small batches. It feels more personal than buying something from a huge brand. The jar lasts forever because you need so little.

Look, it’s not magic. It won’t perform surgery. But if your skin is dry, angry, sensitive, or just confused by modern life, this stuff helps. It’s a reset. It’s going back to basics. It’s what people used before marketing told us we needed twenty steps. There’s something deeply satisfying about using something so simple that works so well.

It’s just… effective. In a quiet, non-shouty way. My skin is happy. I’m happy. That’s the whole review.

**Quick Questions I Get Asked**

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, it can be. Especially if it’s from grass-fed cows. The idea is it’s similar to our skin’s own oils, so it absorbs well and doesn’t just clog stuff up. It’s like giving your skin something it already understands.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
It hasn’t for me, and I can get clogged pores easy. Because it absorbs and mimics sebum, it doesn’t seem to just sit there and cause trouble. But everyone’s skin is different. Start with a little patch test.

**What does bourbon vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
Just really nice, warm vanilla. Not like dessert. Not like a candle. Just a warm, cozy, classic vanilla smell. The “bourbon” part just makes it smell a bit deeper, less sweet. It’s honestly the best-smelling skincare thing I own.

Anyway. If your skin’s being difficult and nothing’s working, maybe give it a shot. It’s less weird than it sounds. I promise.
